questions.text: A 60-year-old man is on bed rest since 10 days. He develops sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain. Which of the following is the best investigation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : a bed rest patient with breathlessness and chest pain we should think of pulmonary embolism. IOC – CT pulmonary angiography.

questions.text: 70-year-old smoker presents with high grade fever, cough and confusion with diarrhea. CXR shows bilateral infiltrates in both lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Na= 126 mEq/ L, AST-62, ALT 56, RBS -112 mg/di and serum Bilirubin 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : This is a case of pneumonia + diarrhea = Legionella Pneumonia + hemolytic anemia = Mycoplasma

questions.text: Which of following is cause of exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation : exudative pleural effusion i.e. inflammation = Rheumatoid arthritis Transudate pleural effusion : MCC ? Cardiac failure Nephrotic syndrome Hepatic hydrothorax Peritoneal dialysis Hypothyroidism

choices.text: Positive skin tuberculin test and positive CR
Negative skin tuberculin test and negative CXR
Positive skin tuberculin test and negative CXR
Negative skin tuberculin test and positive CXR

questions.text: Which is correct about cryptic TB?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : cryptic TB also called Miliary TB. Patient can present with fever/Anemia CXR will be normal. Tuberculin test will be negative, CT chest ? Miliary pattern

questions.text: Child has developed recurrent lung infections with thickened sputum and CXR shows bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : Thick sputum + recurrent infections + bronchial wall thickening + bronchiectasis + steatorrhea these are typical findings of Cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis : abnormality in chloride channel encoded by the CFTR gene because of this there will be very thick secretions. Thick secretions will not allow the pancreas to work properly so there will be pancreatic insufficiency, because of pancreatic insufficiency there will be steatorrhea.

questions.text: A 60/M presents with 18-year history of exposure to asbestos. Which of the following is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : Asbestosis = MC lung cancer(Adeno Ca.) Most specific will be Mesothelioma

questions.text: HIV positive patient develops lung infection. His CD4 count is less than 100cells/ cu.mm and sputum shows acid-fast organism. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : Acid fast organism : Mycobacterium avium and Nocardia But CD4 count is less than 100 cells/cu.mm – Mycobacterium avium is more common.

questions.text: A smoker had developed blood-tinged sputum during cough. On work up Chest X-ray was normal. Which of the following is the next procedure done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation : Smoker + hemoptysis, if chest x-ray is normal, next step should be – CT chest Later – bronchoscopy

questions.text: A male smoker patient who has difficulty in swallowing is most likely to develop which of the following!
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : Squamous cell cancer Lung cancer seen in smoker is usually Small cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma. Option b and c mean the same and are seen in nonsmokers. Option d is also seen in non-smoker and presents with paraneoplastic manifestation of gynecomastia.

questions.text: Comment on ABG report: pH = 7.28 pCO2= 80 mm Hg and HCO3=28mEq/L?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : Respiratory acidosis Since pH is low, acidosis is present. Elevated carbon dioxide levels indicate respiratory etiology. Bicarbonate is on higher side of normal and indicates compensation process has started.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of morning time productive cough that is yellow that increases on turning from left to right side. Which of the following lung diseases is likely to be present?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : Bronchiectasis • The clinical history of purulent (yellow) bronchorrhea with postural variation indicates a reservoir of pus in large airways. This is seen in Bronchiectasis which is characterized by destruction and dilatation of large airways. • Option a can have airway destruction and infection but has associated features like hemoptysis and cachexia. • Option c does not have postural variation of bronchorrhea. • Option d is seen after DVT.

questions.text: DOC for Legionnaires disease!
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation :DOC : Fluroquinolone > Azithromycin The DOC for legionella is now updated to include Levofloxacin apart from Azithromycin and either one can be used.

questions.text: The following image shows
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clubbing The image shows convexity of nails/parrot beak appearance which is seen in clubbing. The color of tips of extremities is normal ruling out Option b, c and d.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who is a known case of lung cancer is having shortness of breath. On examination her neck veins are engorged showing gross elevation of JVP, Heart sounds are distant and breath sounds appear reduced on left side infra-scapular area. CXR is done and is shown below. Comment on the diagnosis of the patient.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cardiac tamponade • The CXR shows an increased CT ratio with narrow vascular pedicle. In a known case of Lung cancer, it indicates metastasis. The patient has developed features of Becks triad. The diagnosis is Malignant pericardial effusion, leading to cardiac tamponade. • The keywords are distant heart sounds with engorged neck veins which point to cardiac tamponade. The pericardial effusion is also encroaching on lung parenchyma leading to reduced breath sounds in infra-scapular area. This is called Ewart sign. • Option a will have loud S1 and narrow split S2 with CXR showing bat wing pulmonary edema • Option b will have bilateral blunting of costophrenic angle • Option d will have flushing of face and mediastinal widening in CXR due to mass effect like lung tumor that is compressing the superior vena cava.

questions.text: Young patient develops bout of acute dysentery. He subsequently develops bilateral ascending quadriplegia. Pain and proprioception sensation is preserved. First differential diagnosis is.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : Acute dysentery is caused my C.Jujuni GBS – Sensory is normal

questions.text: Most common cause of death in diabetic ketoacidosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In DKA, there is severe osmotic diuresis caused by hyperglycemia, leading to massive fluid and electrolyte loss. This results in hypovolemia and dehydration, which can progress to hypotension, shock, and multi-organ failure if not rapidly corrected. Especially in resource-limited settings or when diagnosis is delayed, dehydration can directly lead to death, making it the most common cause overall, particularly in adults. Option B. Cerebral edema: Cerebral edema is a serious complication of DKA, but it is most common in children and adolescents, and is relatively rare in adults. While it can be fatal, it is not the leading cause of death in all DKA patients, especially when looking at a broad population. Option C. Hypokalemia: Although potassium levels can drop during insulin therapy for DKA, and severe hypokalemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, it is typically monitored and managed as part of standard DKA treatment. Death from hypokalemia is uncommon when proper protocols are followed. Option D. Sepsis: Sepsis may act as a trigger for DKA or complicate it, especially in elderly or immunocompromised patients. However, it is not the most frequent direct cause of death in DKA itself. Its role is secondary compared to volume loss from dehydration.

questions.text: Child presents with fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. LP was done and shows 75% mono-nuclear cells with CSF sugar = 50 mg (Blood sugar 100 mg/dl) and protein is 3000 mg/dl. CXR of patient shows upper lobe involvement with hilar enlargement. Diagnosis is? lymph node
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation : In Bacterial meningitis glucose is extremely low (CSF) 10-20

questions.text: Female presents with history of taking OCP and headache for last 6 months which worsens on recumbent position and improves as day progresses. Fundus examination shows Papilledema. There is no focal neurological deficit. MRI shows raised ICP. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : There is a triad of Headache , NO focal neurological deficit , Papilledema = Pseudotumor cerebri.

questions.text: Most common cause of Cushing syndrome in 68yr old male
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation : MCC – Iatrogenic But most common endogenic cause - Pituitary Micro-adenoma.

questions.text: Young patient has sudden onset of severe headache, but he has never had a headache as bad as this one. He is hypertensive but non-diabetic and has nuchal rigidity. Probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : He has never had a headache as bad as this one – Thunder headache.

questions.text: Patient with ptosis, muscle weakness which increases at the end of day which gets relieved with Neostigmine. Diagnosis is? (drooping progresses as day progresses)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation Cholinesterase Inhibitor – peripheral = Myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Hypoglossal nerve injury?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tongue deviation to same side Explanation : Whichever side the lesion is present the tongue is deviated to the same side.

questions.text: A female patient presents with fever for past 3 days and cannot touch neck to chest. LP was done, and CSF findings are: Opening pressure= increased Appearance= White cloudy Cells= Neutrophils predominantly seen CSF Sugar = 15 mg/dl. Protein: 100mg/dL
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bacterial meningitis Explanation : Ref: Harrison 21s ed. pg. 1102 • In a clinical setting of fever with nuchal rigidity and turbid CSF showing predominantly neutrophils and low CSF sugar( normal CSF sugar= 2/3rd of Blood sugar), Acute bacterial meningitis is confirmed. • Option b has predominant lymphocytes with straw color CSF. • Option c has normal CSF sugar and is hence ruled out. • Option d, Fungal meningitis occurs in patients with reduced immunity.

questions.text: Young male 25 years of age presents with Ptosis which is worse in the evening and shows improvement in the morning. The patient complains of exertional fatigue. Work up with ice pack test shows relief in ptosis. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) M. Gravis Explanation : • The main key word is diurnal variation of neurological symptoms with ptosis being worse in evening and relieved in morning. Ice pack test has now replaced Tensilon test to diagnose myasthenia gravis. • Option a presents with dementia and chorea. • Option b has gradual onset asvmmetrical motor weakness developing over years and does not show any diurnal variation in symptoms.

questions.text: Young patient developed sudden anset fever and agitated behavior for 2 days. No meningeal signs were noted. EEG shows periodic focal Temporal lobe spikes, CSF shows-40 cells with 90% lymphocytes and 10% neutrophils with normal CSF Sugar and slight elevation protein. Which of the following should be started in the patient!
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acyclovir Explanation : • Short history points to bacterial/viral etiology of CNS infecton. Absence of nuchal rigidity rules out meningitis. • CSF finding of lymphocytosis and normal sugar points to viral encephalitis. • The leading cause is herpes simplex-1 that has prediliction to damage temporal lobe of brain. Supportive of this is EEG finding of periodic temporal spikes. • Hence patient should be started empirically on acyclovir. • Option a is used in TB meningitis. Option c in acute bacterial meningitis. Option d is used for fungal meningitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with HbAIC 8% comes to ER with hemiplegia 8 hours prior to consult. NCCT head shows intracerebral bleed. BP 198/110 mm Hg. Which of the following intervention is best scheduled for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IV Labetalol Explanation : Ref; Harrison 204 ed. p8. 334 Target BP – 140/90. • Option a thrombolysis will Contra-indicated hemorrhagic stroke. • Option c causes sudden unpredictable fall of BP and can worsen brain infarction. Option d is ruled out as fligh BP needs to be manage in this case to value of 160/90 mm Hg. Recent trials have shown that acute and rapid lowering of BP to less the 140 mm Hg have better functional outcome.

choices.text: Start levothyroxine at 100 microgram and decrease the dose gradually
Start levothyroxine at 25 microgram and increase the dose gradually
Start levothyroxine at 25 microgram and decrease the dose gradually

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with weakness, lethargy, excessive cold intolerance and slow ankle jerk. On TFT. TSH-16mU/L (normal: 0.4-4.0 mU/L) and T40.3 ng/ dL (normal: 0.6-1.6 ng/dL) and T3 70 pg/dl. (normal: 230-619 pg/dl.). What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Start levothyroxine at 25 microgram and increase the dose gradually Explanation : Since TSH is elevated and T4 and T3 are reduced it implies primary hypothyroidism. In patient with no residual thyroid function starting dose is 100-150 micrograms. However in this case since T3 and T4 are being produced starting dose would be 25 ug per day

questions.text: A patient was asked to copy the clock face made by the physician. The image on right is made by the patient. Which is correct about this image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hemi-neglect Explanation : In the right aungular gyrus. The Clock Drawing Testis a simple and effective cognitive test used to assess executive function and visual-spatial test lion. It is a reliable screening tool for cognitive dysfunction, particularly for dementia. Loss of visuospatial skills is called as apraxia. Major visuospatial errors seen on the CDT given in image 1. Right/Left reversal 2. Omitting one half of the clock

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with repeated myoclonic jerks and dementia. Which is the most probable etiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) V-CID Explanation : Ref: Harrison 20% ed. pg. 3149 • Dementia in young age with myoclonic jerks is seen with CNS infection in patients consuming tainted beef products. The prion particles ingested are small enough to cross blood brain barrier and result in neurodegeneration. This presentation is called as variant creutzfeldt Jacob disease. • Option a presents with dementia in patients with atherosclerotic risk factors. • Option b is seen in old age only • Option d presents with chorea and not myoclonic jerks.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with weakness in right arm for a duration of four hours. The weakness gradually became lesser and resolves. She is a known case of Hypertension and BMI is elevated. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Transient ischemic attack Explanation : • Since the neurological features have resolved they indicate the presence of TIA. Stroke features would not resolve by themselves. • Transient ischemic attack is a warning symptom of stroke where the neurological features resolve by themselves In 24 hours and neuro imaging is normal. • Option b presents with radicular pain and focal weakness. Important cause can be disc prolapse that presses on nerve roots. • Option c presents with ascending flaccid paralysis with sensory level and bladder/Bowel involvement. • Option d has been ruled out as features of stroke can cause incapacitation and debility.

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic had his last drink 48 hours ago. He develops anger and rage attacks and appears unable to identify faces of family members and can see inanimate objects. He has been brought to the ER. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Delirium tremens Explanation : Ref: Harrison 20th ed. Pg. 3282 • Agitation, global confusion, disorientation, hallucina-tions, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis, autonomic hyperactivity and profound global confusion are hallmark of Delirium Tremens. • Alcoholic hallucinosis is a ruled out as it is characterized by predominantly auditory hallucinations that occur either during or after a period of heavy alcohol consumption. • Korsakoff psychosis – Dimmentia with cunfabulation • Wernicke's encephalopathy – G-O-A triad.

questions.text: A patient presents with head, hand enlargement with gynecomastia and lactation. Where is the tumor located?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior pituitary Explanation : Ref: Harrison 20th ed. pg. 2678-79 • Increase GR and Increase PRL • Head size and hand size enlargement point to the etiology of acromegaly/gigantism. The cells involved are somatrophs or somato-lactotrophs. • Somatolactotrophs produce excess of growth hormone as well as prolactin. This explains the concomitant gynecomastia and galactorrhea occurring in the patient. The tumor is located in anterior pituitary.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cushing syndrome Explanation : Ref: Harrison 20th ed. pg. 2725 • The image shows purple striae on flanks and anterior abdominal wall. The diagnosis to be considered is Cushing Syndrome. • Option b will produce acanthosis nigricans which has hyperpigmentation in neck folds and axilla. • Option c is associated with skin tags • Option d does not have any associated skin findings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with complaints of palpitations and weight loss. On examination sinus tachycardia is present, and the following lesion was noticed on the shin of the patient. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hyperthyroidism Explanation : Ref: Harrison 20th ed. pg. 2703 • The image shows pretibial myxedema which is a characteristic feature of Graves disease. • Option a is ruled out due to presence of weight loss and sympathomimetic symptoms • Option c leads to lymphedema of legs and genitals • Option d is present since birth with lymphedema.

questions.text: 20-year-old patient developed URTI infection and 10 days later presents with peri-orbital edema with RBC in urine and 800mg protein/ g of urinary creatinine. BP =140/90 mm Hg and C3 levels are reduced. Anti-DNA-ase antibody is present. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation : PSGN : latent period is 1-3 weeks, time between upper respiratory infection and kidney involvement along with the presence of antibody anti-DNA-ase.

questions.text: Patient presents with hemoptysis and hematuria. Anti GBM antibody is seen. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : Hemoptysis and hematuria is Pulmonary – Renal syndrome along with Anti GBM antibody i.e. Good Pasteur syndrome.

questions.text: A young presents with gastric outlet obstruction and vomiting. Which of the following fluid will be used!
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) NS Patients with multiple vomiting episodes will develop dehydration. This leads to activation of RAAS system and increased aldosterone values. Increased Aldosterone leads to increased urinary loss of potassium and hydrogen and causes Hypokalemic Alkalosis. The fluid of choice for correction of metabolic alkalosis is Normal Saline.

questions.text: A Female has difficulty in standing up from squatting position, cannot comb her hair and has violaceous heliotrope rash around upper eye lid. The presentation is of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The patient is having proximal muscle involvement which is a feature of Myositis syndrome, violaceous heliotrope rash means there is cutaneous involvement also i.e. Dermatomyositis.

questions.text: Post-menopausal woman presents with knee pain. Joint aspiration was done and shows needle shaped negatively birefringent crystals in polarized microscopy. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Explanation : There is knee involvement, presence of needle shaped negatively birefringent crystals makes the Dx. of Gout Gout is typical in middle aged male (30-50 yrs) with 1st MTP > Ankle joint. Mono-sodium urate crystal (needle shape), inflammatory mono-arthritis, strong negative birefrigerance.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with throbbing unilateral headache, nodular thickening along the temporal artery. Biopsy of vessels shows giant cells and granulomatous vasculitis. The likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation : Post menopausal patient with unilateral headache, the Dx. is GCA There is granulomatous vasculitis, so therefore Dx. becomes Temporal arteritis (Gaint Cell Arteritis)

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with focal seizures. CT shows multiple ring enhancing granulomas. Which of the following is not to be given immediately in next 24 hours?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Calcitonin is a marker of which malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Calcitonin is a tumor marker specifically associated with medullary thyroid cancer (MTC). MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid, which normally produce calcitonin. In medullary thyroid cancer, there is elevated production of calcitonin, making it a useful diagnostic and monitoring marker for this type of thyroid cancer. Incorrect Options: A. Papillary thyroid cancer Papillary thyroid cancer typically does not have elevated calcitonin levels. It is more often associated with the presence of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor mutations and thyroglobulin as a marker for diagnosis and monitoring. B. Follicular thyroid cancer Follicular thyroid cancer, like papillary thyroid cancer, does not typically produce calcitonin. It is more associated with thyroglobulin levels, which is a marker for follicular and papillary thyroid cancers. D. Anaplastic thyroid cancer Anaplastic thyroid cancer is an aggressive form of thyroid cancer that typically does not produce calcitonin. It is often diagnosed by histopathological examination rather than through specific tumor markers like calcitonin.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman is being evaluated for excessive daytime sleepiness and forgetfulness which have been present for the past 1 year. Her BMI is 43, her BP is 170/98 mmHg. In an awake state, ABG shows pOz 70 mmHg, pCO253 mmHg, HCO 33 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 40-year lady presents with difficulty in eating due to persistent dry mouth. She also has grittiness in eyes due to dry eyes. On examination dental caries is noted with enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Possible diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: 60-year-old bedridden patient develops sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain. TPA was done. Which investigation will be useful to confirm the aetiology of this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The clinical scenario describes a patient with a high suspicion of a pulmonary embolism. The patient's bedridden status is a significant risk factor for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to a PE. The symptoms of sudden breathlessness and chest pain are classic for PE. A D-dimer test is a simple blood test that measures the levels of D-dimer, a protein fragment produced when a blood clot breaks down. It's an excellent screening tool because it has a very high negative predictive value. This means if the D-dimer result is negative (normal), a pulmonary embolism can be effectively ruled out in a patient with a low to intermediate pre-test probability. This helps avoid unnecessary and more costly imaging like a CT scan. However, a positive D-dimer test is not specific for PE, as it can be elevated in many conditions (e.g., infection, trauma, surgery, cancer, pregnancy). Therefore, a positive result requires further investigation, such as a CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA), to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: ABCD2 scoring includes all of the following parameters except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A 50 year-old man presents with movement disorder along with development of cognitive and emotional problems. Which of the following medical disorders is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following JVP findings is expected to be seen in a patient with muffled heart sounds, hypotension and raised JVP?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: 50-year-old patient with lung cancer presents with breathlessness and light headedness. On lung auscultation reduced intensity of breath sounds are heard on the left infero-scapular region. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: 23-year-old patients presents with a history of flank Pain and fatigue and history of red coloured urine. On investigation there were more than 20 BC/ HPF and microscopy showed dysmorphic BC. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Elderly male patient with history of COPD, HT and diabetes mellitus is on multiple drugs Which of the following criteria are used to avoid use of certain drugs in these patients?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is least useful in management of patient with Thalamic Dejerine syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about Wolf Parkinson white syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: 70-year-old man presents with low back ache and progressive pallor. On work up KFT is deranged, LFT is normal with normal level of albumin, but gamma globulins are disproportionately increased. X ray Spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following is cell of origin of the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: All the following will show Hypokalemia except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Lymphocytosis, low sugar and high protein
Lymphocytosis, high sugar and high protein
Neutrophils, low sugar and low protein
Neutrophils, low sugar and high protein

questions.text: Child is brought with a 2-week day history of not feeding well and excessive irritability. History of TB in sister in present. In work-up LP was performed. Which of the following is likely to be found in CSF?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset right sided hemiparesis for last 3 hours. BP is - 220 /130 mm Hg. NCCT head showed hyper dense lesion. All of the following are to be done for management except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 60-year-old patient diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke and advised thrombolysis with alteplase, and weight of the patient is 80 kgs. How much dose should be given stat?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with Dialysis dementia what deposition is seen in cerebral cortex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Only basis of patient history X
FEV1 showing increment of more than 15% after giving a bronchodilator

questions.text: Which of the following will help in making a definite a diagnosis of Bronchial asthma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) FEV1 showing increment of more than 15% after giving a bronchodilator A definite diagnosis of bronchial asthma is supported by demonstrating reversible airway obstruction. This is typically shown by an improvement in the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) of more than 12-15% (and at least 200 mL increase) after administration of a bronchodilator. This reversible airflow limitation is a hallmark of asthma and helps confirm the diagnosis. A. Only basis of patient history Patient history is important but not sufficient alone to make a definite diagnosis of asthma. Many respiratory conditions can mimic asthma symptoms, so objective testing is needed. C. Focal Wheezing sound Wheezing is a common symptom but can be heard in other conditions as well (like COPD, bronchitis, or localized airway obstruction). It is not specific enough for a definite diagnosis. D. HRCT chest High-resolution CT of the chest may be helpful in excluding other lung diseases or complications but is not used to definitively diagnose asthma.

questions.text: Patient had an R.T.A and is brought with bradycardia along with high BP. GCS checked came to be less than 8. Next step in management is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Antibody seen in Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy will belong which class?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Reversibility of airflow obstruction in asthma is defined as FEV1 change pre and post bronchodilator to be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: 65-year-old man is brought to hospital with complaints of suddenly not making any sense while speaking using non sensical grammar though he can speak quickly. He could communicate effectively prior to this. Which of the following defect is present in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In Wernicke's aphasia, patients speak fluently with normal or increased speech rate, but their language is often nonsensical, disorganized, or lacking meaning. They often use incorrect or made-up words (paraphasias), and grammar is preserved but meaningless. Comprehension is impaired, and they are often unaware of their language errors. This fits the description in the question exactly. Option A. Broca's aphasia: In Broca's aphasia, speech is non-fluent, slow, and effortful, but comprehension is relatively preserved. The person knows what they want to say but struggles to express it verbally. This patient is speaking fluently, so Broca’s aphasia is not likely. Option B. Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by difficulty in finding the right words, especially nouns and names, but fluency, grammar, and comprehension are largely preserved. This patient is producing nonsensical speech, which is more severe than what’s seen in anomic aphasia. Option D. Conduction aphasia: Conduction aphasia involves fluent speech and good comprehension, but poor repetition and frequent phonemic errors (mispronunciations). Speech may be interrupted by attempts to self-correct, but it is not usually described as completely nonsensical. So, this does not match the case.

questions.text: Which of the following test is used for short term diabetic control?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serum fructosamine is the correct option for assessing short-term diabetic control. Explanation: Serum fructosamine measures the amount of glucose bound to serum proteins, primarily albumin. Since albumin has a shorter half-life (about 2-3 weeks) compared to hemoglobin (which HbA1c measures and has a lifespan of about 2-3 months), serum fructosamine provides an average of blood glucose control over the preceding 2 to 3 weeks. This makes it an ideal indicator for assessing short-term glycemic control, useful for monitoring recent changes in treatment or lifestyle, especially in situations where HbA1c might be affected by red blood cell lifespan variations.

questions.text: Scissoring gait will occur due to increased firing in which of the following nerve?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Patient presented with pedal edema, raised JVP till mandible and ascites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cardiac failure

questions.text: 30-year-old lady presents with recurrent episodes of epistaxis and perennial runny nose. He has been passing cola-colour urine off and on. Recently for work up of haemoptysis multiple cavitary lesions were noted in both lungs. Which of the following tests would help in confirming diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: 20-year-old male who is an intravenous drug user presents with fever for last one week (38.5 C). On work up TLC is 20000/cu.mm, blood culture report is pending, and spots are noted on fundus examination. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for diagnosis of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: 13-year-old girl presents with increased bleeding post dental extraction. Since local hemostatic measures PT was done and report is normal. Which of the following is the correct about the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: 40 kg female patient admitted in hospital for past one week is currently having multiple episodes of seizures. On work up Serum sodium of 120 meq/L. Calculate the Total correction to be given to this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of pain and pressure sensation behind her left eye. The orbital pain was associated with intermittent proposis. The symptoms and signs were increased on exercise and Valsalva maneuvers. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: What can be given to eat in celiac sprue?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which of the following set of value suggest primary hypothyroidism:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Pneumo-mediastinum is found in which of the following condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following is used for assessing long-term glucose control:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Lady with Hypertension presents with seizures. BP on admission is 220/120 mm Hg. Best for his/her management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: 21-year-old guy presents with episodes of chest pain. Physical examination shows pulsus bisferiens and heaving apex. Comment on diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Arrange the following auscultatory areas in order:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Systolic Blood pressure exp>10 mm Hg than inspiration

questions.text: 50-year-old man with h/o TB presents with complaints of pedal edema and abdominal distention. Neck veins are prominent. CXR is shown below. Which of the following findings will be likely seen in this patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Adult Patient collapses in ER and you are giving CPR with your medic in the ER. What is ratio of Chest compressions to rescue breaths?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 45-year-old lady with obstructive lung disease is on salmeterol and tiotropium but still is having breathlessness and increased exacerbations. Which of the following is best for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Kussmaul sign is NOT seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Rescue PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention) is done in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which is not correct about Carcinoid tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Patient after undergoing kidney transplantation reports drop in output and rising serum creatinine. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A young lady had recurrent headaches, easy bruising and episodes of visual blurring. Platelet count was increased. RBC & WBC count was normal. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 30-year-old woman presents with generalized muscle weakness, ptosis and double vision that worsens with activity and improves on rest. She has difficulty in chewing and swallowing in evening hours. Which of the following is best to confirm her diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SFEMG (Single-Fiber Electromyography). Explanation: While anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibody testing (Option C) is a common and specific initial diagnostic test for Myasthenia Gravis (MG), its sensitivity can vary, especially in cases of ocular MG or "seronegative" MG where antibodies are not detected. SFEMG, however, is considered the most sensitive electrophysiological test for detecting impaired neuromuscular transmission, a hallmark of MG. It directly measures the "jitter" (variability in the timing of muscle fiber action potentials) and "blocking" (failure of muscle fibers to activate) which are characteristic abnormalities in MG. Therefore, even when antibody tests are negative or ambiguous, an abnormal SFEMG can definitively confirm the presence of a neuromuscular junction disorder consistent with Myasthenia Gravis, making it the best confirmatory test

questions.text: A 30 years old lady presented with unilateral throbbing headache which aggravates on exposure to bright light. She skips her breakfast occasionally. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Patient presents with complaints of fever, headache and vomiting episodes for past 2 weeks. On examination nuchal rigidity is noted with following LP report Opening pressure: elevated Cells= Neutrophil predominance Sugar= 50 mg/d Protein= 105 mg/dl Comment on appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which wall of myocardium is involved this patient presenting with chest pain and ECG findings shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior wall

questions.text: Faget sign/ relative bradycardia is seen which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Diabetic man does strenuous work out and develops prostration and collapses. Which drug is likely to cause this manifestation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: HIV positive patient presents with cough and difficulty in breathing. CD4 count is 200 cells/cu.mm. CXR is shown below. Select the right combination for the case
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Patient presents with shortness of breath. On examination left parasternal heave is noted with palpable liver. On auscultation systolic murmur is heard. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pulmonic stenosis

questions.text: Graham Steele murmur is heard in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pulmonic regurgitation

questions.text: Young man c/o palpitations. ECG shows absent P wave with irregular RR interval. BP 80/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DC shock

questions.text: Known case of rheumatic heart disease presents with dyspnea. On examination water hammer pulse and pistol shot sound over femoral arteries is heard. Auscultation shows early diastolic murmur. Identify the valvular lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aortic regurgitation

questions.text: Known case of mitral regurgitation presents with shortness of breath. CXR shows bilateral peri hilar haziness. Which is correct about this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute pulmonary edema

questions.text: What is the determinant of severity of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) S2- Opening snap gap

Normal PR followed by dropped beats
Prolonged PR interval with RR shortening

questions.text: Correct about Mobitz I heart block
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gradual prolongation of PR followed by dropped beats

Prolonged PR and normal RR interval
Prolonged PR and prolonged RR interval

questions.text: Which is correct about 1st degree heart block?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prolonged PR and prolonged RR interval

questions.text: Patient presented with pain on left side of the chest radiating to left arm and shoulder for last 20 minutes. ECG shows ST depression in precordial leads. What is next best step in management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aspirin + Clopidogrel

choices.text: Infra-nuclear facial palsy on right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on right side
Infra-nuclear facial palsy on left side
Supranuclear facial palsy on left side

questions.text: A patient has weakness of lower half of face left side with drooping of mouth. He is not able to rise his eyebrows and close eyes. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Infra-nuclear facial palsy on left side Explanation: The key to diagnosing facial palsy lies in understanding the innervation of the facial muscles and how lesions at different levels affect them. The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) supplies all muscles of facial expression. It has an upper and lower motor neuron component. The forehead muscles (frontalis, orbicularis oculi for eye closure) receive bilateral innervation from the motor cortex (both cerebral hemispheres contribute). In contrast, the muscles of the lower half of the face (around the mouth) receive primarily contralateral innervation (from the opposite cerebral hemisphere). When a lesion occurs at the level of the facial nerve nucleus or distal to it (infranuclear lesion), it affects all muscles supplied by that nerve on the ipsilateral (same) side. This means weakness of the entire half of the face (forehead, eye, and lower face) on the side of the lesion. In this patient: "Weakness of lower half of face left side with drooping of mouth" indicates weakness of the lower facial muscles on the left. "Not able to rise his eyebrows and close eyes" indicates weakness of the upper facial muscles (forehead and eye closure) on the left. Since both the upper and lower halves of the left side of the face are affected, this points to an infranuclear facial palsy on the left side (C). This is characteristic of conditions like Bell's palsy or other peripheral facial nerve lesions. Now, let's analyze why the other options are incorrect: A. Infranuclear facial palsy on right side: This would cause weakness of the entire right side of the face, which contradicts the patient's symptoms being on the left side. B. Supranuclear facial palsy on right side: A supranuclear lesion (e.g., a stroke in the motor cortex) affects the motor pathways before they reach the facial nerve nucleus. Due to the bilateral innervation of the forehead, a supranuclear lesion typically spares the forehead and eye muscles, affecting primarily the contralateral lower half of the face. So, a supranuclear lesion on the right side would cause weakness of the lower half of the left face, with sparing of the left eyebrow and eye closure. This contradicts the patient's inability to raise eyebrows and close eyes. D. Supranuclear facial palsy on left side: A supranuclear lesion on the left side would affect the lower half of the right side of the face (contralateral weakness), while sparing the right eyebrow and eye closure. This also contradicts the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: Patient presents with headache, vomiting and nuchal rigidity. LP was done and shows turbid CSF. Microscopy shows 90% PMN cells with sugar of 40 mg/dL (RBS 120 mg/dl) and protein of 200 mg/dl. Which is correct about management of this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ceftriaxone plus vancomycin

questions.text: A patient presents with history of viral infection 3 weeks back. He then develops ascending bilaterally symmetric lower limb flaccidity and weakness over next week. On examination DTR absent. The likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, nausea, and vomiting. The symptoms improve after taking sumatriptan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Migraine

questions.text: A 6-month child is noted to have muscle weakness. Vitals Pulse: 80/min, BP 70/50 mm Hg. Work up shows metabolic alkalosis with hypokalaemia. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bartter syndrome

questions.text: In a patient with electric burns and stable vital signs, red-colored urine is observed. What is the most likely finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increased CPK levels

questions.text: Patient with anasarca is found to have proteinuria of 4.5 gm/day. What is the recommended treatment for this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Steroids

questions.text: Patient presents with vomiting episodes. Interpret the ABG report of pH: 7.53, pCO2 48 mm Hg and HCO3: 33 meq/L?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Pancoast tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Exophthalmos

questions.text: Patient had a fight in a party followed by vomiting episode and he collapsed. Percussion shows hyper resonance and absent breath sounds on right side. CXR shows tracheal shift to left side. Which is likely finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tension Pneumothorax

choices.text: Drug interaction between ATT drugs and ART

questions.text: Patient with TB and AIDS is started on ART. He reports worsening of the symptoms of fever and malaise. Which of the following is likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome

choices.text: Pleural protein ratio less than 0.5 of serum protein
Pleural LDH less than 2/3rd of serum LDH
Pleural LDH less than 0.6 of serum LDH

questions.text: What is the expected finding in the pleural fluid analysis for parapneumonic effusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pleural pH less than 7.2

questions.text: Patient sustained a road traffic accident and fracture of femur. After 48 hours he has breathing difficulty. Which is first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fat embolism

questions.text: A Smoker comes with complaint of dyspnea. Spirometry shows FEV1 60% and FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.6. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) COPD

questions.text: A female patient presents with difficulty ingesting liquids more than solids. What is the most likely characteristic finding on imaging?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bird beak appearance

questions.text: Patient with liver cirrhosis presents with breathing difficulty due to massive ascites. Which is incorrect statement?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SAAG < 1.1

questions.text: Diabetic patient presents with pedal edema and dyspnea due to CHF. Which of following drugs shows cardio renal benefit?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) SGLT inhibitors

questions.text: Chvostek sign is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Alcoholic patient presents with gum bleeding. On examination delayed wound healing and cork screw hair is noted. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Vitamin C

questions.text: Alcoholic patient presents with palpitations, dizziness, and syncopal attacks. On examination, irregularly irregular pulse is seen. What will be seen on JVP?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Absent a wave Explanation : Alcohol is associated with risk of Atrial fibrillation. Atrial fibrillation can lead to the symptoms mentioned in the question. Due to high Atrial rate > 350 bpm, the contractions are ineffective and hence, JVP hows Absent a wave.

questions.text: 25-year-old female with previous history of rheumatic fever. Examination shows loud S1 and mid diastolic murmur is having which of the following valvular heart disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MS Rheumatic fever most commonly affects the Mitral valves. MS is the only female dominant valve defect. Loud S1 with MDM favors MS. TS can come with same auscultation findings, but, is unlikely as Tricuspid valve is not affected in rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A patient presents to ER with central chest pain. He has a past medical history of heart disease. ECG is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterolateral MI ECG shows ST segment elevation in Leads I,avL, V3-V6 and hence the diagnosis. Acute pericarditis comes with generalised ST elevation. Inferolateral MI will involve Leads II, III, aVF and V4-V6.

questions.text: A patient after MI develops broad qRS complex tachycardia. His BP is 120/85 mm Hg. ECG is given below. Best management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Amiodarone iv Broad QRS tachycardia with Regular HR favours Ventricular tachycardia. Since BP is normal, the first line treatment is IV Amiodarone. In presence of Shock, the best would have been DC Cardioversion.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight gain, thinning of hair and dry skin. Diagnosis is Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Which antibody is seen in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anti-TPO antibody The Questions describes symptoms of hypothyroidism. The most common cause of hypothyroidism in the world is Autoimmune thyroiditis i.e. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. MC antibody found is Anti-TPO, hence the answer.

questions.text: RTA patient has received 4 packed RBC within few hours. Which of the following will be seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypocalcemia Massive blood transfusion can cause hypocalcemia due to citrate toxicity. Stored Blood contains Citrate which binds to calcium leading to toxicity.

choices.text: Voltage gated calcium channels at NMJ

questions.text: A young female presents with ptosis showing diurnal variation. CT chest shows anterior mediastinal mass identified as thymus gland cancer. Which receptor is affected in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) post synaptic NMJ Fluctuating weakness is a hallmark of NMJ defect. In a young female with Thymoma, the most likely disease is Myasthenia gravis. It is a post-synaptic defect of NMJ with antibodies against the Acetylcholine receptors (AcHR).

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with progressive limb weakness for past 1 year. On examination muscle fasciculations and hypertonia is noted and sensory system is intact. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ALS Presence of UMN (Hypertonia) and LMN signs( Fasciculations) favours motor neuron disease. Most common is ALS.

questions.text: A patient presents with symmetrical leg weakness and areflexia. He had developed diarrhoea 2 weeks ago. He was diagnosed as having GBS. What is the cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Demyelination of A,B fibers. Symmetrical paraplegia with areflexia following diarrhea favours diagnosis of GBS. GBS is acute demyelinating polyneuropathy affecting A and B fibers.

questions.text: A patient develops cough and weight loss for last 3 months. Biopsy of lung mass shows expression of chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which paraneoplastic syndrome will most likely occur in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) SIADH Chronic cough with weight loss favours lung cancer. Biopsy findings suggest SCCL. Small cell carcinoma expresses chromogranin & synaptophysin, often causing SIADH more than Ectopic ACTH (Cushing’s syndrome)

choices.text: Thickening of posterior auricular nerve + lepra reaction type 1
Thickening of greater auricular nerve + lepra reaction 1
Thickening of posterior auricular nerve + lepra reaction type 2
Thickening of greater auricular nerve + lepra reaction 2

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the presentations shown below? (Image shows a close-up of a person's neck/ear area with an arrow pointing)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Greater auricular is a the most commonly thickened nerve in leprosy; Type 1 reaction is reversal reaction with localized inflammation. Image shows thickened nerve and Hence the answer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with headache and nuchal rigidity. NCCT head shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SAH Headache with rigidity can be seen in Meningitis and SAH. However, hyperdensity in the cisterns on CT scan confirms SAH (Blood in ventricles).

questions.text: A patient presents with palpitations, headache and sweating. His BP is 180/100 mmHg. 24-hour urinary metanephrine values are elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pheochromocytoma Elevated urinary metanephrine levels are diagnostic of Pheochromocytoma.

choices.text: Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2

questions.text: Patient with osteoarthritis, for last 3 months, is taking ibuprofen and has developed occult GI bleeding. Which is correct about the cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PGE-2 and prostacyclin reduced NSAIDs block COX ? ? mucosal protection ? GI bleed.

questions.text: HIV-positive patient presents with chronic diarrhoea for 4 weeks. Stool microscopy shows oval/elliptical cysts measuring 16 X 20 μm. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cryptoisospora Cystoisospora belli causes large oval cysts and chronic diarrhea in HIV. Cryptosporidium — Smaller cysts (4-6 µm); acid-fast. Cryptococcus — Causes meningitis, not diarrhea. Cyclospora — Smaller cysts (8-10 µm).

questions.text: A known case of hyperthyroidism, who is not on medication, is scheduled for total thyroidectomy. PAC check was not done properly. What is the leading complication that can occur during surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Arrythmia Improper control of hyperthyroidism pre-operatively can lead to thyroid storm leading to risk of tachyarrythmias.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with deep seated retro-orbital pain of cluster headache. What is the best management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oxygen Retro-orbital pain in a young male can be excruciating and favours cluster headache. The best treatment to abort the attack is high flow Oxygen.

questions.text: Patient presents with hypertension and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. CT scan shows mass over the kidney with elevated ARR. What is the next best step for management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adrenalectomy Hypokalemia metabolic alkalosis favours Aldosterone excess states. Hypertension favours primary hyperalsosteronism. With mass over the kidney, the diagnosis is likely to be Conn’s syndrome which can be cured by adrenalectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is having chronic hypercalcemia for last 1.5 year but PTH levels are normal. Which of the following is most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malignancy. Hypercalcemia with normal or low PTH suggests non-PTH mediated causes like malignancy. In Sarcoidosis — Granulomas increase 1,25-OH Vit D; PTH suppressed. In Parathyroid hyperplasia and CKD — raised PTH, not normal levels.

choices.text: Bedside CXR in casualty followed by chest tube insertion

questions.text: On examination, a person has distended neck veins, absent breath sounds, hyperresonance and shift of trachea. What is the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Wide bore needle in 2nd ICS — Absent breath sounds favours pneumothorax. Immediate needle decompression in pneumothorax is lifesaving. Imaging delays treatment.

questions.text: A female presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Serum prolactin is elevated. MRI shows pituitary adenoma. Best management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bromocriptine The diagnosis in the question is a Pituitary adenoma with high prolactin levels. In both Microadenoma and Macroadenoma, the first line treatment is Dopamine agonist like Bromocriptine/Cabergoline if PRL is elevated.

questions.text: A child with progressive pallor and bone has an elevated HbS based on HPLC report. Which is best treatment to manage hemolysis in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hydroxyurea. HbS favours Sickle cell anaemia. To prevent sickling, we have to prevent hypoxemia by increasing concentration of HbF i.e fetal Hb. Hydroxyurea increases HbF levels and hence the answer.

questions.text: Pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma results in which visual field defect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bitemporal hemianopia Optic chiasmal tumour compresses optic chiasma causing above defect.

questions.text: A young male patient has the following serological status: HbsAg positive, IgM anti Hbc negative, IgG Anti-Hbc positive and HBeAg positive. Select the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lamivudine The Question describes Chronic Hepatitis B with active replication (HBeAg) Hence needs antiviral treatment with Lamivudine/Tenofovir. Ombitasvir is used for Chronic Hepatitis C infection. Ritonavir and Abacavir are for HIV infection.

questions.text: A patient with RTA is passing red color urine due to myoglobinuria. Which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hyperkalemia RTA causes muscle breakdown leading to myoglobinuria. The release of potassium from the muscles, causes hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient after RTA had a renal shut down. His work up shows FeNa value < 1% and urine osmolality value of 500 mosm/L. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pre-renal AKI The FeNa less than 1% and concentrated urine favours prerenal azotemia.

questions.text: A patient is in ICU and there is a failed attempt of subclavian catheterization. BP drops and pulse rises. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pneumothorax Pneumothorax is a known and common complication of Subclavian catheterization.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA. NCCT head was normal. Patient died after few days of ICU admission for coma and brain biopsy of brain shows multiple punctuate haemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diffuse axonal injury. In DAI, early CT may be normal; microscopic axonal shearing ? punctate hemorrhages in corpus callosum and brainstem.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and altered sensorium. Peripheral smear shows multiple ring stages. Best treatment is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Artesunate Altered sensorium favours cerebral malaria (Falciparum) Artesunate is the best treatment due to increasing chloroquine resistance.

questions.text: HPV is strongly associated with which of the following cancers?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oropharyngeal cancers. It is a factual question.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with diarrhoea, constipation and malabsorption. On examination pigmentation on lips and mouth is seen. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Peutz-Jeghers — is characterized by hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation (lips, oral mucosa). There is associated bowel symptoms.

questions.text: What defect is seen in Bernard soulier syndrome? BSS---sticking problem GTA: Grabbing fibrinogen issue
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) GpIb — Binds vWF, essential for platelet adhesion; deficient in BSS.

questions.text: A patient presents with SOB and fatigue. CXR was done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Silicosis Cement factory worker is prone to Silicosis. Asbestosis has bilateral upper lobe infiltration and hence not the answer.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive shortness of breath for the last 6 months, accompanied by dry cough. Auscultation reveals bilateral basal end-inspiratory crepitations. There is no history of fever, joint pain, or occupational exposure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) IPF End inspiratory crepitations are typical of Interstitial lung diseases. ILD’s can be caused by Occupational exposure, Autoimmune disease and drugs. Since the question has symptoms of neither, by exclusion, the best answer is Idiopathic Pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)

questions.text: RTA patient with fracture of shaft of femur. 3 days later, he develops SOB and drop in SaO2. D-Dimer is elevated. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) FES FES — Classic triad: respiratory distress, neurological signs, petechiae; occurs post long bone fracture on 2-5th day. Pulmonary embolism — Possible, but more common with DVT than fracture.

questions.text: A patient has a long arm span, hypermobile joints and hypermobile lens. What is the defective protein?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fibrillin 1 The history is suggestive of Marfan’s syndrome which is mostly associated with Fibrillin 1 defect.

questions.text: A child presents with kawasaki disease with multiple large coronary artery aneurysms. Treatment is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Aspirin + clopidogrel 6 weeks — Dual antiplatelet therapy recommended in coronary aneurysms to prevent thrombosis.

questions.text: Infant is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of seizures. ECG shows Hypsarrhythmia. Which drug is preferred for management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ACTH Hypsarrythmia on EEG is characteristic of Infantile spasm which best responds to ACTH.

questions.text: Patient presents with contralateral face, arm, and leg weakness. NCCT shows ICH. What is the location of CNS bleed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Basal ganglia The MC site of IC bleed is Basal ganglia. Few students recall Pinpoint pupils, in which case, the answer will be pontine hemorrhage.

choices.text: Subendocardial ischemia due to increased demand of myocardium
Increased sympathomimetic drive in morning hours

questions.text: A female patient complaints of chest pain while waking up in morning. Pain is more in winter months. Which of the following best describes this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ACh-induced vasoconstriction — Pain worsening with stress/cold exposure is Typical of Prinzmetal/variant angina due to coronary artery spasm. Majority attacks tend to occur early morning. Hence the answer.

questions.text: CSF shows abundant neutrophils with low sugar and elevated proteins. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ABM — Classic triad: low glucose, high protein, neutrophils in CSF. In TBM — Shows lymphocytes, high protein, low sugar. In Viral encephalitis — CSF shows lymphocytosis, normal glucose. In Viral meningitis — Same as above.
